questions.text:
A 60-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of nausea, headache, and generalized fatigue for 2 days. He has not vomited. He was diagnosed with small cell lung cancer and liver metastases around 3 months ago and is currently receiving chemotherapy with cisplatin and etoposide. His last chemotherapy cycle ended one week ago. He has chronic obstructive lung disease and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Current medications include insulin and a salmeterol-fluticasone inhaler. He appears malnourished. He is oriented to time, place, and person. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 87/min, respirations are 13/min, and blood pressure is 132/82 mm Hg. There is no edema. Examination shows decreased breath sounds over the left lung. Cardiac examination shows an S4. The abdomen is soft and nontender. Neurological examination shows no focal findings. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
11.6 g/dL


Leukocyte count
4300/mm3



Platelet count
146,000/mm3



Serum



 Na+

125 mEq/L


 Cl−

105 mEq/L


 K+

4.5 mEq/L


 HCO3−

24 mEq/L


 Glucose
225 mg/dL


 Total bilirubin
1.1 mg/dL


 Alkaline phosphatase
110 U/L


 AST
78 U/L


 ALT
90 U/L


Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following set of laboratory findings?



Serum osmolality
Urine osmolality
Urinary sodium excretion



A
220 mOsm/kg H2O
130 mOsm/kg H2O
10 mEq/L


B
269 mOsm/kg H2O
369 mOsm/kg H2O
82 mEq/L


C
255 mOsm/kg H2O
45 mOsm/kg H2O
12 mEq/L


D
222 mOsm/kg H2O
490 mOsm/kg H2O
10 mEq/L


E
310 mOsm/kg H2O
420 mOsm/kg H2O
16 mEq/L
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This is the expected laboratory finding in patients with hypervolemic hyponatremia (e.g., due to cirrhosis or congestive heart failure). Despite hypervolemia, effective circulating volume is diminished (from low cardiac output in congestive heart failure or splanchnic vasodilation in cirrhosis), causing the kidneys to incorrectly detect a state of hypovolemia. Subsequent activation of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system and secretion of antidiuretic hormone leads to a net effect of reabsorption of a greater amount of free water than sodium, resulting in hyponatremia. Although this patient does have signs of liver damage (likely from metastasis and cisplatin therapy), these do not suggest cirrhosis (only mildly elevated liver enzymes, absence of ascites).

B) CORRECT:

SIADH will result in free water reabsorption in the kidneys by increasing aquaporins in the distal convoluted tubules and collecting ducts. Excess free water retention causes low serum osmolality (< 280 mOsm/kg) and hyponatremia (< 135 mEq/L), as well as concentrated urine (> 100 mOsm/kg). Since the patient is euvolemic and therefore does not retain sodium through activation of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system, there will be normal to high urine sodium excretion (> 20–30 mEq/L).
Image Description:

FENa: fractional excretion of sodium
SIADH: syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion
TURP: transurethral resection of the prostate
UNa: urine sodium
UOsm: urine osmolality

C) INCORRECT:

These would be the expected laboratory results in primary polydipsia. An excess in free water intake will lower serum osmolality and cause a compensatory reduction in the secretion of antidiuretic hormone, which will dilute urine to a maximum (reducing urine osmolality) to excrete excess fluid. Urine sodium excretion will remain low, however, as the kidneys will respond to reduced serum osmolality by reabsorbing sodium. This patient does not have a history of drinking excessive amounts of fluid, making these findings unlikely.

D) INCORRECT:

These would be the expected laboratory findings in patients with extrarenal fluid loss (e.g., vomiting, diarrhea), indicating hypovolemic hyponatremia. Loss of sodium and free water will decrease effective circulating volume and cause secretion of antidiuretic hormone and activation of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system. Therefore, urinary sodium excretion is decreased and osmolality is elevated as the kidneys work to reabsorb free water and sodium from the urine. The net effect is retention of more free water than sodium, resulting in hyponatremia. As the patient has not had any vomiting or diarrhea, this diagnosis is unlikely.

E) INCORRECT:

These would be the expected laboratory results in hypertonic hyponatremia (e.g., due to hyperglycemia). In hyperglycemia, excess glucose will increase the serum osmolality and cause hyponatremia through water shift (osmosis) from the intracellular to the extracellular space (serum sodium levels decrease by 1.6 points for each 100 mg/dL glucose above normal). The actual sodium content does not change. Glucose excreted in the urine will cause elevated urine osmolality and urine sodium excretion will be low due to likely hypovolemia from osmotic diuresis and subsequent activation of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system. Although this patient does have elevated glucose levels (225 mg/dL), this does not account for the degree of his hyponatremia.
questions.hint: Small cell lung cancer is commonly associated with paraneoplastic syndromes such as syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion (SIADH). Nausea, headache, and fatigue in this patient are likely due to the hyponatremia caused by this paraneoplastic syndrome.

questions.text:
A 58-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her husband because of increasing confusion and generalized fatigue over the past week. During this period, she has had muscle cramps, headaches, nausea, and vomiting. Six days ago, she underwent resection of a parasagittal meningioma. She tolerated the procedure well without complications and was discharged two days ago. She has hypercholesterolemia and hypertension. Current medications include oxycodone, acetaminophen, atorvastatin, and lisinopril. She is oriented only to person and place. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 89/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 142/88 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 97%. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Serum studies show:


Serum



 Na+

126 mEq/L


 K+

3.6 mEq/L


 Cl-

107 mEq/L


 Urea nitrogen
16 mg/dL


 Glucose
87 mg/dL


 Creatinine
0.9 mg/dL


 Osmolality

263 mOsmol/kg H2O


Urine



 Osmolality

523 mOsmol/kg H2O


 Sodium

44 mEq/L


Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?

choices.text: Syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cerebral salt wasting syndrome, which may occur in patients after neurosurgical procedures, is a poorly understood cause of hypovolemic, hypotonic hyponatremia. Patients with cerebral salt wasting syndrome have a low serum osmolality, as seen here, but also present with symptoms of hypovolemia (e.g., hypotension, tachycardia) and paradoxical polyuria.

B) CORRECT:

Syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion (SIADH) can occur following injury to the CNS and is an important differential diagnosis to consider for any neurosurgery patient presenting with hyponatremia. SIADH causes euvolemic hypotonic hyponatremia. Increased activity of antidiuretic hormone decreases free-water clearance, which results in a low serum osmolality (< 280 mOsmol/kg H2O), and inappropriately concentrated urine (> 100 mOsmol/kg H2O). Since patients with SIADH are typically euvolemic and therefore do not retain sodium through activation of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system, there will be normal to high urine sodium excretion (> 20–30 mEq/L). Given the severity of this patient's hyponatremia, she should be treated with restriction of oral fluids and administration of hypertonic saline. The correction of hyponatremia should be gradual (maximum increase of 10–12 mmol/L within 24 hours, or 0.5 mmol/L/hour) and under ICU observation, as rapid correction can lead to central pontine myelinolysis. In patients with SIADH and severe hyponatremia, the use of vasopressin receptor antagonists such as tolvaptan may be considered if serum sodium either continues to drop or fails to rise by 2 mmol/L after 24 hours.
Image Description:

FENa: fractional excretion of sodium
SIADH: syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion
TURP: transurethral resection of the prostate
UNa: urine sodium
UOsm: urine osmolality

C) INCORRECT:

Opioids such as oxycodone can cause sedation, confusion, nausea, and vomiting in postoperative patients, even at normally prescribed doses. However, patients with an opioid overdose present with miosis and respiratory depression. This patient has a normal respiratory rate, is not hypoxemic, and does not have pinpoint pupils on examination.

D) INCORRECT:

Primary polydipsia (psychogenic polydipsia) leads to euvolemic hypotonic hyponatremia, as seen here. However, this patient does not complain of excessive thirst, and there is no history of the patient drinking unusual amounts of water. Moreover, patients with primary polydipsia and hyponatremia have decreased urine sodium levels (< 20–30 mEq/L) and a urine osmolality less than 100 mOsmol/kg (maximally diluted urine).

E) INCORRECT:

Mineralocorticoid deficiency (hypoaldosteronism) would result in hyponatremia with decreased serum osmolality (hypotonic hyponatremia) and urine sodium levels > 20–30 mEq/L. However, patients present with signs of hypovolemia (e.g., hypotension, tachycardia), hyperkalemia, and a normal anion gap metabolic acidosis. This patient has a normal K+ level and is euvolemic.
questions.hint: Serum osmolality and volume status are important for differentiating the etiology of hyponatremia. This patient's serum osmolality is low (hypotonic) and she does not have edema or signs of hypovolemia, making her euvolemic. Euvolemic hypotonic hyponatremia in the context of recent neurosurgery is suggestive of a specific underlying condition.

questions.text:
Two days after being admitted to the hospital following a fall, a 77-year-old woman reports fatigue and headaches. During the fall she sustained a right-sided subdural hematoma. She has hypertension and hyperlipidemia. Her medications prior to admission were enalapril and atorvastatin. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical and neurologic examinations show no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:


Serum



 Na+

130 mEq/L


 K+

4.0 mEq/L


 Cl-

103 mEq/L


 HCO3-

24 mEq/L


 Urea nitrogen
14 mg/dL


 Creatinine
1.1 mg/dL


 Osmolality
270 mOsmol/kg H2O


Urine



 Osmolality
326 mOsmol/kg H2O


A CT scan of the head shows an unchanged right-sided subdural hematoma. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Head elevation, as well as avoiding neck flexion/rotation or circumstances that may provoke Valsalva responses, are important actions to take when dealing with elevated intracranial pressure (ICP). This woman's history of head trauma is concerning for elevated ICP, especially since a subdural hematoma was noted on admission. With new-onset headache, further evaluation of the hematoma is necessary. However, since it appears to be stable and she is hyponatremic, this particular intervention is unlikely to provide relief of her symptoms.

B) INCORRECT:

Demeclocycline, a tetracycline, is helpful in treating SIADH because it acts as an antagonist to antidiuretic hormone within the kidney. However, this therapy is reserved for symptomatic patients, or when initial interventions fail to correct hyponatremia.

C) INCORRECT:

Tolvaptan is a vasopressin receptor antagonist, which makes it a useful drug for treating SIADH. This therapy is reserved for symptomatic patients, or when multiple interventions fail to correct hyponatremia.

D) INCORRECT:

Desmopressin is a synthetic vasopressin (i.e., antidiuretic hormone) analog used to treat central diabetes insipidus. Increasing antidiuretic hormone in this woman would make her hyponatremia worse.

E) CORRECT:

Fluid restriction is the first-line treatment for nonsevere, nonacute hyponatremia associated with SIADH. Intake of fluids must be decreased to the point where excretion of free water is greater than the intake of free water. A negative water balance reverses the dilutional hyponatremia that resulted from water retention induced by antidiuretic hormone. If fluid restriction fails to adequately increase serum sodium levels, pharmacological therapy with vasopressin receptor antagonists (e.g., tolvaptan) is indicated.

In patients with acute hyponatremia and/or severely symptomatic hyponatremia (e.g., altered mental state), hypertonic saline should be administered immediately.

F) INCORRECT:

Mannitol is an osmotic diuretic used to treat cerebral edema, elevated intracranial pressure, and acute angle-closure glaucoma. It acts to pull water into the nephron and reverse the dilutional hyponatremia. However, it causes large increases in urine output that can lead to dehydration and hypernatremia if not monitored closely. Mannitol is not used in the treatment of SIADH.

G) INCORRECT:

Hypertonic saline is used for hyponatremia with severe symptoms (e.g., seizures, altered mental status, coma), which can be seen in some cases of SIADH. Because this patient's symptoms are mild (e.g., headaches, fatigue), another treatment should be tried first.
questions.hint: This patient has mild hyponatremia and her urine is more concentrated than her blood. These findings in a patient with recent head trauma are suggestive of syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion (SIADH).

questions.text:
A 50-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his wife because of lethargy and confusion for the past 24 hours. He has also had a productive cough for the past year and has had a 10-kg (22-lb) weight loss over the past 6 months. He has a history of multiple sclerosis and has not had an acute exacerbation in over 10 years. For the past 30 years, he has smoked two packs of cigarettes daily. He drinks two beers every day after work. He appears lethargic and is not oriented to person, place, or time. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 130/90 mm Hg. Physical examination shows scattered wheezing bilaterally. Deep tendon reflexes cannot be elicited. Laboratory studies show:


Serum



 Na+

115 mEq/L


 K+

4.5 mEq/L


 HCO3-

22 mEq/L


 Glucose
70 mg/dL


 Blood urea nitrogen
8 mg/dL


Urine



Osmolality
450 mOsmol/kg H2O


An x-ray of the chest shows a central lung mass. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Order CT scan of the chest

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A CT scan of the chest could be useful for evaluating the lung mass seen on the chest x-ray, but it would not address the immediate clinical needs of this patient with altered mental status and significant hyponatremia.

B) INCORRECT:

Adding a loop diuretic, such as furosemide, may be considered for severe hyponatremia after initial management, which has not yet been initiated. Additionally, loop diuretics are generally most effective in the management of hyponatremia if the urine osmolality is greater than two times the serum osmolality (typically urine osmolality > 500 mOsmol/kg).

C) CORRECT:

Hypertonic (3%) saline is indicated for patients with acute hyponatremia and/or severely symptomatic hyponatremia (e.g., altered mental status, hyporeflexia) to reverse neurological symptoms and prevent brain herniation. This patient's hyponatremia is likely caused by SIADH resulting from ectopic production of antidiuretic hormone (e.g., in small cell lung carcinoma). In severe cases, adding a loop diuretic (e.g., furosemide) should be considered, especially if urine osmolality is more than twice the serum osmolality. If initial measures fail, demeclocycline or vasopressin receptor antagonists such as tolvaptan may be considered.

Patients with severe hyponatremia are at risk of osmotic demyelination syndrome if sodium is corrected too quickly and should therefore be monitored in an ICU setting. After initial stabilization, fluid restriction is recommended for the treatment of hyponatremia associated with SIADH.
Image Description:

BMP: basic metabolic panel
FENa: fractional excretion of sodium
ICP: intracranial pressure
IV: intravenous
NaCl: saline solution

D) INCORRECT:

Fluid restriction is the first-line treatment for nonacute, nonsevere hyponatremia associated with SIADH. This patient has hyponatremia with severe neurological symptoms, including altered mental status and hyporeflexia. Restriction of all fluids is recommended, but initial stabilization is required first.

E) INCORRECT:

Demeclocycline can be used to treat hyponatremia. However, it takes several days to one week for demeclocycline to decrease the responsiveness of the collecting tubule to antidiuretic hormone and subsequently increase water excretion. Adequate sodium repletion can be achieved by using another treatment with fewer side effects and lower costs.

F) INCORRECT:

Conivaptan is a vasopressin receptor antagonist that can be used to treat severe hyponatremia if initial management fails. Conivaptan may cause overly rapid correction of sodium in severely hyponatremic patients.
questions.hint: Altered mental status, severe hyponatremia, and concentrated urine (urine osmolality ≥ 100 mOsml/kg) in a patient with a central lung mass are consistent with syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion (SIADH).

questions.text:
A 55-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his daughter because of the gradual onset of confusion since this morning. His daughter reports that the patient had been complaining of worsening headaches, nausea, and generalized weakness for the past 2 days. He has a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus; his last HbA1c was 8.3% 4 months ago. Three months ago, he was diagnosed with polyarteritis nodosa. His symptoms did not improve despite treatment with corticosteroids; pulse therapy with cyclophosphamide was recently added to his regimen. His other medications include insulin and a daily multivitamin. Temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 91/min and regular, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 138/85 mm Hg. Physical examination shows normal skin turgor and moist mucous membranes. He is arousable and oriented to person, but not place or time. There are no focal neurological deficits. Several erythematous nodules are present over the bilateral lower extremities. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:


Serum



Na+
127 mEq/L


 K+

3.8 mEg/L


 Cl-

94 mEq/L


 HCO3-

22 mEq/L


 Glucose
200 mg/dL


 Osmolality

265 mOsmol/kg H2O


 Creatinine
1.1 mg/dL


 Uric acid
2.1 mg/dL


Urine



 Na+

46 mEq/L


 Osmolality

332 mOsmol/kg H2O


Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's laboratory abnormalities?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Dehydration due to volume depletion can manifest with nausea, vomiting, and generalized weakness in mild to moderate dehydration and altered mental status (e.g., confusion, disorientation, lethargy) in severe cases. However, patients with dehydration typically present with hypernatremia and high serum osmolality due to the reduction in total body water, low urine sodium excretion, clinical signs of dehydration (e.g., dry mucous membranes, decreased skin turgor), and abnormal vital signs (i.e., hypotension, tachycardia). This patient has hyponatremia, low serum osmolality, no clinical signs of dehydration (normal skin turgor, moist mucous membranes), and vital signs within normal limits indicating a euvolemic state.

B) CORRECT:

Drug-induced syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion (SIADH) is an adverse effect of cyclophosphamide, which results in unrestricted secretion of antidiuretic hormone. Untreated SIADH leads to hyponatremia, manifesting with nausea, vomiting, weakness, and in severe cases, altered mental status (e.g., confusion, disorientation). Laboratory studies show low serum sodium and low serum osmolality due to excessive free water retention, as well as hypouricemia (due to increased urinary uric acid clearance) and concentrated urine (due to inappropriate reabsorption of water). Cessation of the offending drug is the first step in management. In addition to being a possible adverse effect of medications (chlorpropamide, carbamazepine, cyclophosphamide, selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors), SIADH can be caused by intracranial infections (i.e., meningitis, encephalitis), malignancies (especially small cell lung carcinoma), pulmonary diseases (pneumonia, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease), and stroke.

The skin lesions on this patient's lower extremities are most likely due to polyarteritis nodosa, which commonly involves the cutaneous system and manifests with ulcerations, erythematous nodules, eruptions, or livedo reticularis.
Image Description:

(1) Receptors in the hypothalamus measure plasma osmolality. If the osmolality exceeds a set point, ADH is released in the hypothalamus.
(2) ADH travels from the hypothalamus to the posterior pituitary via the neurosecretory hypothalamo-neurohypophyseal tract.
(3) ADH is released from the posterior pituitary into the bloodstream.
(4) ADH increases renal reabsorption of water (inclusion of aquaporins in the collecting tubules).
(5) Reabsorption of water results in decreased urination.
(6) Receptors in the hypothalamus detect falling osmolality and reduce ADH secretion.

C) INCORRECT:

Excessive water intake (e.g.. due to psychogenic polydipsia) can result in hyponatremia and low serum osmolality. However, patients with excessive water intake typically have low urine osmolality due to the body's attempt to excrete excessive free water; this patient's urinalysis shows concentrated urine indicating excessive free water reabsorption.

D) INCORRECT:

Adrenal insufficiency can result in hyponatremia due to reduced aldosterone secretion. However, hypoaldosteronism also results in hypovolemia, hyperkalemia, and mild hyperchloremic metabolic acidosis. In addition, excessive loss of sodium and water as opposed to concentrated urine would be expected.

E) INCORRECT:

Cerebral ischemia (i.e., stroke) can cause syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion, which can manifest with dilutional hyponatremia, decreased serum osmolality, and concentrated urine, as seen here. Although this patient presents with altered mental status, neurological evaluation shows no focal deficits or additional signs of cerebral ischemia, making this diagnosis less likely.

F) INCORRECT:

Acute kidney injury can result in hyponatremia due to the kidney's inability to reabsorb sodium. However, this patient lacks additional signs of kidney injury including oliguria, signs of uremia, elevated creatinine, and inability to concentrate the urine.
questions.hint: This patient has dilutional hyponatremia (serum sodium < 135 mEq/L and serum osmolality < 275 mOsmol/kg) and inappropriately concentrated urine (urinary sodium > 20 mEq/L and urine osmolality > 100 mOsmol/kg). These findings are likely due to unrestricted secretion of antidiuretic hormone from the pituitary gland.

questions.text: A 75-year-old man with a seizure disorder is brought to the emergency department by a friend because of progressive confusion over the past two weeks. He is unable to provide any history. His vital signs are within normal limits. He appears lethargic and is only oriented to person. Oral mucosa is moist. There is no jugular venous distention. A basic metabolic panel shows a serum sodium concentration of 115 mEq/L but is otherwise normal. Serum osmolality is low and antidiuretic hormone level is elevated. X-ray of the chest shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s hyponatremia?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Low cardiac output (e.g., due to congestive heart failure) results in hypervolemic hyponatremia due to low renal perfusion and subsequent activation of RAAS and ADH secretion, which in turn stimulates water (and sodium) reabsorption. This patient lacks other signs of low cardiac output, including pitting edema, pulmonary edema, and/or elevated JVP, making this etiology unlikely.

B) INCORRECT:

Hyperglycemia (e.g., from type 1 diabetes mellitus) can cause both hypovolemic and/or dilutional hyponatremia. Hypovolemic hyponatremia is a characteristic feature of diabetic ketoacidosis and occurs due to the osmotic diuresis from hyperglycemia and glucosuria. In dilutional hyponatremia, increased serum osmolality from hyperglycemia causes water to shift from the intracellular to the extracellular space, resulting in a decreased serum sodium concentration. This patient's normal metabolic panel and euvolemia on exam make hyponatremia due to hyperglycemia very unlikely.

C) INCORRECT:

Aldosterone deficiency (e.g., due to adrenal insufficiency, type 4 RTA, or congenital hypoaldosteronism) can also manifest with hyponatremia and elevated ADH due to decreased sodium resorption in the collecting ducts. This patient does not have characteristic signs or symptoms of aldosterone deficiency, such as hyperkalemia, metabolic acidosis, or hypotension.

D) CORRECT:

SIADH is an adverse effect of several medications, including carbamazepine, SSRIs, and cyclophosphamide and is characterized by an inappropriately elevated serum ADH despite low plasma osmolality (e.g., the patient is not hypovolemic). Risk factors for developing medication-induced SIADH include older age (> 65 years old), concomitant use of other antiseizure drugs and diuretics, and a history of hyponatremia. Other causes of SIADH include CNS disorders, pulmonary disease, and ectopic production of ADH (e.g., small cell lung cancer).

E) INCORRECT:

Increased levels of cortisol (e.g., Cushing syndrome) classically manifest with hypernatremia, not hyponatremia. Other characteristic laboratory findings include hypocalcemia, hyperglycemia, and hypokalemia.
questions.hint: This patient is euvolemic and has a low serum sodium level with high ADH levels, suggesting a diagnosis of SIADH.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after a witnessed tonic-clonic seizure. His wife says he has had a persistent dry cough for 6 months. During this time period, he has also had fatigue and a 4.5-kg (10-lb) weight loss. The patient has no history of serious illness and does not take any medications. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 35 years. He is confused and oriented only to person. Laboratory studies show a serum sodium concentration of 119 mEq/L and glucose concentration of 102 mg/dL. An x-ray of the chest shows an irregular, poorly demarcated mass at the right hilum. Microscopic examination of this mass is most likely to confirm which of the following diagnoses?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although squamous cell lung carcinoma is the most common lung cancer in smokers and can also manifest with a central mass, it is not typically associated with SIADH. Instead, it causes hypercalcemia due to the release of parathyroid hormone-related protein (PTHrP).
Image Description:

Click on the Smartzoom button to view the entire specimen through a virtual microscope.

B) CORRECT:

Microscopic examination of this hilar density is most likely to reveal a small cell lung carcinoma. SIADH is one of the common paraneoplastic syndromes associated with SCLC; others include Cushing syndrome and Lambert-Eaton syndrome.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a lung tissue specimen (H&E stain, high magnification)

There are sheets of small cells with hyperchromic, pleomorphic nuclei, and minimal cytoplasm. Mitotic figures are present. The stroma appears delicate and scant compared to the sheets of abnormal cells.

These findings are consistent with small cell lung carcinoma.

C) INCORRECT:

Large cell lung carcinoma is unlikely since it typically has peripheral localization and is not associated with SIADH. In some cases, it may cause paraneoplastic secretion of G-CSF or gynecomastia due to secretion of the beta subunit of β-HCG.

D) INCORRECT:

A bronchial carcinoid tumor is unlikely in this patient because it is not associated with SIADH. Instead, it can cause carcinoid syndrome (due to ectopic serotonin secretion).

E) INCORRECT:

While lung adenocarcinoma is the most common type of lung cancer overall, it is associated with hypercoagulability, thrombophlebitis migrans, and nonbacterial verrucous endocarditis rather than SIADH. Additionally, lung adenocarcinoma typically has peripheral localization on imaging, unlike this patient's findings.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a lung tissue sample (H&E stain; 400x magnification)

Several confluent tubular glands lined by atypical epithelium (examples indicated by green outline) and surrounded by desmoplastic hypercellular stroma are visible. There is nuclear stratification (nuclei located at different heights within the epithelium rather than basally only), nuclear hyperchromasia (darker stained nuclei), and pleomorphism (different sizes of cells and nuclei).

These are typical findings in acinar adenocarcinoma of the lung.
questions.hint: Hyponatremia in a smoker with weight loss and persistent cough suggests a paraneoplastic syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion (SIADH).

questions.text:
A 70-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by staff of the group home where he resides because of worsening confusion for the past week. He has a history of major depressive disorder and had an ischemic stroke 4 months ago. Current medications are aspirin and sertraline. He is lethargic and disoriented. His pulse is 78/min, and blood pressure is 135/88 mm Hg. Physical examination shows moist oral mucosa, normal skin turgor, and no peripheral edema. While in the waiting room, he has a generalized, tonic-clonic seizure. Laboratory studies show a serum sodium of 119 mEq/L and an elevated serum antidiuretic hormone concentration. Which of the following sets of additional laboratory findings is most likely in this patient?



Serum osmolality
Urine sodium
Serum aldosterone



A
↑
normal
normal


B
↓
↓
↓


C
↑
↓
normal


D
↓
↓
↑


E
↓
↑
↑


F
↓
↑
↓
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The combination of high serum osmolality, normal urine sodium, and normal serum aldosterone is consistent with an elevated osmolal gap, e.g., due to ingestion of toxic alcohols or glycols, which can manifest with confusion, lethargy, and seizure. While hyperosmolality directly stimulates ADH release, it also causes polydipsia due to increased thirst, and polyuria due to osmotic diuresis, neither of which is present in this patient. Furthermore, an elevated osmolal gap would not explain the severe hyponatremia seen in this patient. In addition, nothing in this patient's history suggests he has ingested a toxic alcohol or glycol.

B) INCORRECT:

The combination of low serum osmolality, low urine sodium, and decreased serum aldosterone is consistent with primary polydipsia, which is often associated with schizophrenia or obsessive-compulsive disorder. However, primary polydipsia is not usually associated with major depressive disorder or a history of stroke. In addition, elevated levels of ADH would not be consistent with primary polydipsia.

C) INCORRECT:

The combination of high serum osmolality, low urine sodium, and normal serum aldosterone in a patient with elevated serum ADH levels is consistent with nephrogenic diabetes insipidus. Patients with nephrogenic DI can present with altered mental status, lethargy, and seizures due to dehydration. However, nephrogenic DI causes hypernatremia, not hyponatremia as seen in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

The combination of low serum osmolality, low urine sodium, and elevated serum aldosterone is consistent with hypovolemic hyponatremia due to an extrarenal fluid loss (e.g., gastrointestinal) or hypervolemic hyponatremia due to liver cirrhosis or CHF (edematous state). Although either condition could manifest with confusion, lethargy, and seizures, patients would not have normal skin turgor (signs of dehydration in hypovolemic hyponatremia; edema in hypervolemic hyponatremia), as this patient does. Moreover, neither condition is associated with a history of ischemic stroke or sertraline use.

E) INCORRECT:

A combination of low serum osmolality, high urine sodium, and high serum aldosterone is consistent with an intrinsic renal disease like type 4 renal tubular acidosis due to aldosterone resistance. Type 4 RTA is characterized by impaired sodium reabsorption in the distal tubule (hyponatremia). Aldosterone resistance can be due to ARBs, potassium-sparing diuretics, trimethoprim or pentamidine, but sertraline does not cause aldosterone resistance. Moreover, symptoms of type 4 RTA would also include polyuria, polydipsia, and signs of dehydration (e.g., decreased skin turgor and hypotension), none of which is present in this patient.

F) CORRECT:

SIADH manifests with hypotonic hyponatremia and decreased serum aldosterone. ADH increases the expression of aquaporin-2 channels in the distal convoluted tubules and the collecting ducts of nephrons. This increases the resorption of solute-free water from urine into systemic circulation, which concentrates the urine (hypernatriuria), increases urine osmolality, dilutes serum (hyponatremia), and decreases serum osmolality. The resulting hyponatremia causes the osmotic shift of fluid into cells, which may cause cerebral edema, increased intracranial pressure, and, ultimately, confusion, lethargy, and seizures. Patients remain euvolemic (euvolemic hyponatremia) because transient plasma volume expansion increases ANP secretion, which decreases aldosterone secretion, leading to natriuresis and the inhibition of sodium reabsorption in the collecting duct.
questions.hint: This patient has hyponatremia and elevated ADH despite appearing euvolemic on examination, which suggests syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion (SIADH). SSRI use (e.g., sertraline) and stroke are both associated with the development of SIADH.

questions.text:
A 64-year-old postmenopausal woman presents to the emergency department (ED) 10 days after transsphenoidal resection of a 3.8-cm suprasellar mass that was detected on MRI after temporal visual-field defects were found on routine eye examination. Preoperative evaluation revealed normal chemistries, normal thyroxine and cortisol levels, a prolactin level of 36 ng/mL (reference range, 0–20), and inappropriately low gonadotropin levels.
After surgery, the patient experienced gradual restoration of her visual fields. On postoperative laboratory evaluation, her complete blood count, comprehensive metabolic panel, cortisol and free thyroxine levels were all normal. Today, the patient presents to the ED with generalized weakness. Her blood pressure and heart rate are within normal limits. Her mucous membranes are moist, and she has no peripheral edema. The rest of the physical examination is unremarkable.
Follow-up laboratory testing, conducted at 8 a.m., yields the following results:

Which one of the following treatments is indicated for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Conivaptan is an intravenous vasopressin-receptor antagonist that is approved for treating euvolemic hyponatremia. It is not indicated in a patient who is recovering from pituitary surgery, given that the syndrome of inappropriate secretion of antidiuretic hormone is usually transient in this setting, and the hyponatremia is not severe.

B) INCORRECT:

Desmopressin, a synthetic form of antidiuretic hormone, is used to treat central diabetes insipidus, which is another possible complication of transsphenoidal surgery. However, central diabetes insipidus is characterized by polyuria, polydipsia and, typically, an elevated serum sodium level.

C) INCORRECT:

Furosemide is indicated in hypervolemic hyponatremia, such as that due to congestive heart failure.

D) INCORRECT:

Adrenal insufficiency and central hypothyroidism are excluded by the finding of normal cortisol and free thyroxine levels, respectively, so replacement with hydrocortisone and levothyroxine would be ineffective.

E) CORRECT:

Hyponatremia that occurs approximately 7 to 10 days after transsphenoidal surgery points to a diagnosis of the syndrome of inappropriate secretion of antidiuretic hormone (SIADH), which is a known late complication of transsphenoidal surgery. SIADH is usually transient, and the treatment is daily fluid restriction.

Key learning point: Hyponatremia that develops one week after transsphenoidal surgery in a patient with normal cortisol levels and normal thyroid function should prompt consideration of a diagnosis of the syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion.

questions.text:
A young man, 19 years of age, is evaluated for hyponatremia 7 days after transsphenoidal surgery for a suprasellar mass. Before his surgery, he had presented with fatigue, weight gain, cold intolerance, and double vision on lateral gaze. Endocrine testing revealed a low morning- cortisol level, central hypothyroidism, and secondary hypogonadism. Cerebral imaging revealed a 1.5-cm by 1.5-cm suprasellar mass that contained calcifications and displaced the optic chiasm anteriorly.
Preoperatively, he was treated with hydrocortisone 20 mg in the morning and 10 mg in the evening, as well as levothyroxine 100 μg daily.
His endocrine medications were continued postoperatively. On postoperative day 2, his urine output was 350 mL/hour, and he noted increased thirst. His serum sodium level rose to 148 mEq/liter (reference range, 135–145) before normalizing. Now, 7 days postoperatively, his serum sodium level is 128 mEq/liter.
Which one of the following diagnoses is the most likely cause of hyponatremia in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Pseudohyponatremia, characterized by a marked elevation in serum lipid or protein levels, causes a decreased fraction of serum to water and an artificially low serum-sodium level. This diagnosis is unlikely because the patient does not have a history of these predisposing conditions and was hypernatremic several days earlier.

B) CORRECT:

Hyponatremia is typically caused by water retention rather than loss of sodium. Water retention is typically mediated by an elevation in antidiuretic hormone (ADH) levels, often as a result of volume depletion, decreased effective arterial blood volume, postoperative pain, nausea, and spinal injury. The diagnosis of the syndrome of inappropriate secretion of antidiuretic hormone (SIADH) requires clinical euvolemia, which under normal circumstances would not be associated with increased ADH release. SIADH is caused by the nonosmotic release of ADH. After transsphenoidal surgery, there is often a triphasic response, with an initial polyuric phase (24 hours to 5 days after surgery) that reflects postoperative inhibition of ADH release, followed by SIADH that results from the release of stored ADH (6 to 12 days after surgery) from damaged neurons; a third phase may result in permanent diabetes insipidus, which can indicate permanent damage to the hypothalamus.

Key learning point: The triphasic water and sodium abnormalities that follow transsphenoidal surgery consist of the phases of transient central diabetes insipidus, followed by a phase of inappropriate release of antidiuretic hormone, and then (potentially) permanent diabetes insipidus.

C) INCORRECT:

Central adrenal insufficiency that occurs after an operation is more likely to be in the immediate postoperative period, not 7 days later. However, this condition is unlikely in a patient who is already being treated with appropriate replacement doses of glucocorticoids.

D) INCORRECT:

Growth-hormone deficiency would not cause hyponatremia.

E) INCORRECT:

Diabetes insipidus is characterized by persistent hypernatremia (>145 mEq/liter) rather than hyponatremia, because it causes a free-water diuresis, resulting in a relative deficit of water.

questions.text:
A 42-year-old woman reports one month of nausea, difficulty concentrating, and forgetfulness. She has a history of trigeminal neuralgia, and her neurologist recently prescribed carbamazepine, which is the only medication that has provided her with pain relief.
She describes a normal diet and what she believes are normal water and salt intake. Her blood pressure is 120/75 mm Hg, and her heart rate is 70 beats per minute. Physical examination is unremarkable; she has no edema or orthostatic changes.
Laboratory results are as follows:

Urine studies reveal a sodium level of 65 mEq/liter and an osmolality of 430 mOsm/kg.
What is the most appropriate initial management for this patient?

choices.text: Infusion of one liter of 0.9% saline
Fluid restriction to one liter daily
Infusion of one liter of 3% normal saline

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Administration of normal saline would be inappropriate in this patient, because it would lead to a further reduction in the serum sodium level. When the urine osmolality is fixed, due to SIADH, at 430 mOsm/kg, as in this case, then the kidneys will excrete the 300 mOsm contained in one liter of normal saline in around 0.7 liters of urine (as calculated by dividing 300 mOsm by the 430 mOsm/kg). That leaves 0.3 liters of free water that the kidney cannot excrete; this water is retained and will dilute the serum sodium level further. Normal saline is therefore not appropriate whenever the urine osmolality is higher than the osmolality of normal saline.

B) INCORRECT:

Loop diuretics may be added to fluid restriction in patients with volume overload and hyponatremia related to heart failure or liver failure. In addition to the direct effects of these agents in treating volume overload, loop diuretics are also beneficial because they interfere with the maintenance of the renal medullary gradient, so use of these agents tends to limit the maximal urine concentration to about 300 mOsm/liter. Because this is not highly concentrated, patients with urine osmolality in this range require a less-strict limitation on fluid intake.

C) CORRECT:

Antidiuretic hormone (ADH) is released primarily in response to an increase in the osmolality of the blood; a secondary stimulus is severe volume depletion. ADH acts on the principal cells of the renal collecting ducts to stimulate reabsorption of water, which maintains normal serum osmolality. If severe hypovolemia is the trigger for ADH release, then the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS) is also stimulated, which leads to increased reabsorption of sodium from the urine, with a resulting urine sodium level that is very low.

When other stimuli, including medications such as carbamazepine, induce the release of ADH, the resulting water reabsorption is inappropriate; thus, this situation is called the syndrome of inappropriate ADH secretion (SIADH). With inappropriate ADH release, there is dilution of the serum sodium and other electrolytes, leading to hyponatremia and low or low-normal levels of other solutes such as blood urea nitrogen and uric acid. Patients are euvolemic in this situation; the RAAS is therefore not stimulated, and the urine sodium level is therefore not low. The urine sodium level can thus be a helpful parameter in distinguishing SIADH from appropriate ADH release due to hypovolemia. Of note, severe hypothyroidism and adrenal insufficiency both lead to ADH release and can lead to hyponatremia with water intake. These diagnoses should therefore be excluded before a diagnosis of SIADH is made.

If the hyponatremia in a patient with SIADH is mild to moderate and the patient (as in this case) is either asymptomatic or has only mild symptoms, the mainstay of therapy should be fluid restriction. Ongoing normal insensible losses with limited fluid intake will lead to a slow rise in the serum sodium concentration toward normal.

If the hyponatremia in a patient with SIADH is severe, a hypertonic fluid, such as 3% sodium chloride, can be given. Hypertonic saline provides solute that is used to excrete the excess water.

Key learning point: Appropriate initial management for hyponatremia caused by the syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion (SIADH) consists of fluid restriction.

D) INCORRECT:

If the hyponatremia in a patient with SIADH is mild to moderate and the patient (as in this case) is either asymptomatic or has only mild symptoms, the mainstay of therapy should be fluid restriction. Ongoing normal insensible losses with limited fluid intake will lead to a slow rise in the serum sodium concentration toward normal. Oral protein or urea supplements can be added to fluid restriction if the serum sodium level does not rise with conservative management alone. An alternative is oral sodium chloride tablets, although this approach may lead to thirst, which can limit the ability of the patient to adhere to fluid restriction.

E) INCORRECT:

If the hyponatremia in a patient with SIADH is severe, a hypertonic fluid, such as 3% sodium chloride, can be given. Hypertonic saline provides solute that is used to excrete the excess water. If the hyponatremia in a patient with SIADH is mild to moderate and the patient (as in this case) is either asymptomatic or has only mild symptoms, the mainstay of therapy should be fluid restriction.

questions.text:
A 64-year-old woman is evaluated in the emergency department for a fall. She is found to have a fracture of the right distal radius and a serum sodium level of 128 mEq/liter (reference range, 136–145). Her medical history includes hypertension, hypothyroidism, osteoporosis, and depression. She currently takes lisinopril 20 mg daily, amlodipine 5 mg daily, levothyroxine 100 μg daily, sertraline 100 mg daily, and alendronate 70 mg weekly. Other than pain in her right wrist, she feels well, and family members report that she has not been confused.
Her vital signs are within normal limits, and she is oriented to person, place, and time. Examination reveals moist oral mucous membranes, normal skin turgor, and no jugular venous distention or peripheral edema. Other than a cast on the right distal forearm and hand, her physical examination, including a neurologic examination, is normal.
Repeat blood testing 6 hours after the initial testing yields the following results:

What is the most appropriate next step in managing this patient’s hyponatremia?

choices.text: Administer 100 mL of 3% normal saline intravenously
Administer 1 liter of 0.9% normal saline intravenously
Limit intake of free water to 1500 mL daily
Limit intake of all fluids to 1000 mL daily

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Administration of tolvaptan is not advised in this setting. This agent blocks the vasopressin 2 receptor in the collecting ducts of the kidney and effectively blocks ADH. Tolvaptan has no role in the acute management of hyponatremia, as the serum sodium level can rise quickly. Although it is approved for use in chronic SIADH, it is expensive, and hyponatremia can usually be managed without it.

B) INCORRECT:

Administration of hypertonic (3%) saline is not indicated in this patient because she is asymptomatic and the hyponatremia is not severe and can be managed with other, more conservative strategies. Furthermore, use of hypertonic saline requires careful monitoring with serial sodium measurements, and some institutions require an intensive care setting, which is not necessary in this case. Finally, hypertonic saline could increase the serum sodium level too rapidly, which may lead to osmotic demyelination syndrome, although most cases of this devastating neurologic syndrome occur in patients with more severe hyponatremia or other risk factors, such as malnutrition or excessive alcohol use.

C) INCORRECT:

Administration of 0.9% saline is likely to worsen this patient’s hyponatremia. This fluid has an osmolality of 304 mOsm/kg and is therefore much more dilute than the patient’s urine. Given that she is euvolemic, she would excrete the sodium chloride from normal saline but in a smaller, more concentrated volume because of her inability to excrete water in the presence of ADH, resulting in a net gain of electrolyte-free water.

D) INCORRECT:

Limiting only the intake of free water (defined as fluids with little to no sodium content) would allow the patient to continue other fluids. This strategy is likely to worsen her hyponatremia as all consumed fluids except salty soup or bouillon are dilute.

E) CORRECT:

This patient has a low serum sodium level and a low serum osmolality — or hypotonic hyponatremia. She has no clinical history of volume loss and appears euvolemic on examination. The urine osmolality is well over 100 mOsm/kg, which means that the urine is concentrated. However, the urine sodium level is not low, which suggests that the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone axis is not active. This evidence of antidiuretic hormone (ADH) activity without an osmotic or volume stimulus is consistent with the syndrome of inappropriate secretion of antidiuretic hormone (SIADH). In this case, the cause is most likely sertraline, although other etiologies should also be considered.

Given that this patient appears asymptomatic, the hyponatremia is likely to have developed slowly rather than acutely, and correction should be addressed thoughtfully and slowly. Still, it is worth noting that her presentation is from a fall, and there is some evidence that even patients with otherwise asymptomatic hyponatremia are at greater risk for falls. Therefore, efforts at correction are important.

This patient’s urine osmolality is high and thus her urine is very concentrated. If additional fluid is administered, the kidneys will retain the water as they are unable to create dilute urine due to the effects of ADH, but the sodium load can be excreted, leading to retention of the water and worsening of the hyponatremia. Fluid restriction will be a key component of her therapy. Additional strategies to raise the serum sodium level include consuming a high-solute diet with high sodium and protein intake. A high-solute diet provides solute to help excrete water. In addition, a long-acting loop diuretic reduces the medullary concentrating gradient so that the urine is less concentrated and the SIADH is easier to manage. It would also be reasonable to consider discontinuing sertraline as part of the longer-term management strategy in this patient.

Key learning point: Management of asymptomatic, moderate hyponatremia in a euvolemic patient with the syndrome of inappropriate secretion of antidiuretic hormone involves limiting all fluid intake to less than 1000 mL daily.

questions.text:
A 17-year-old girl is admitted after undergoing posterior spinal fusion because of idiopathic spinal scoliosis. There were no intraoperative complications. The patient is receiving maintenance intravenous fluids, and her pain is well controlled with intravenous opioids and benzodiazepines. A urinary catheter is in place.
At 6 hours postoperatively, the nurse notes that the patient's urine output has decreased over the past few hours, from 3.0 to 0.5 mL/kg/hour.
The patient's heart rate is 90 beats per minute, her blood pressure is 122/68 mm Hg, and her weight is 60 kg. She is awake and responsive. Her cardiorespiratory examination is normal. There is no edema, and her capillary refill is <2 seconds.
Laboratory testing yields the following results:



Patient value
Reference range


Sodium (mEq/liter)
129
135–147


Potassium (mEq/liter)
3.4
3.4–4.7


Glucose (mg/dL)
118
70–105


Bicarbonate (mEq/liter)
24
22–26


Blood urea nitrogen (mg/dL)
7
5–18


Serum osmolality (mOsm/kg)
270
275–295


Urinalysis reveals a sodium level of 41 mEq/liter, an osmolality of 600 mOsm/kg, and a specific gravity of 1.030 (reference range, 1.001–1.035).
Which one of the following management approaches is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Administer a bolus of 3% normal saline

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A loop diuretic, such as furosemide, allows the excretion of free water by disrupting the medullary gradient and preventing the formation of maximally concentrated urine. Loop diuretics are a good choice for patients with hypervolemic hyponatremia (as in congestive heart failure) and can also be appropriate for patients who do not respond to water restriction or are moderately symptomatic.

B) CORRECT:

This patient has the syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion (SIADH), which results in an impaired ability to excrete free water. Normal stimuli for secretion of ADH are volume depletion and hypernatremia. When neither of these stimuli is present, the kidneys should be able to dilute the urine to less than 100 mOsm/kg. When the urine is more concentrated than this, it is clear that ADH is present and its release is inappropriate. The urinary sodium level in a patient with SIADH is typically greater than 25 mEq/liter, since volume depletion is not present and the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone axis is not activated. Additionally, the patient must be euvolemic for the diagnosis of SIADH (as in this case).

The decrease in urine output is consistent with the acute development of SIADH. In this 60-kg patient, the urine output of 30 mL/hour (0.5 mL/kg/hr) is an obvious decline but is not considered oliguric.

SIADH can occur for a variety of reasons, including oncologic processes, lung or central nervous system infections, medications, and post-operative pain or nausea.

Management of SIADH depends on the degree, severity, and duration of the hyponatremia. Most mild-to-moderate cases can be managed in the inpatient setting with fluid restriction. In this particular case, the patient is asymptomatic, and fluid restriction is the appropriate initial management. This includes both stopping intravenous fluids and restricting oral fluid intake. When the SIADH resolves, the patient will promptly excrete the excess water.

Key learning point: The first-line treatment for an asymptomatic patient with the syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion is fluid restriction.

C) INCORRECT:

The use of hypotonic fluid such as 5% dextrose in 0.45% normal saline is not appropriate because it may worsen the hyponatremia as more free water is retained.

D) INCORRECT:

Oral sodium supplementation without fluid restriction would not be a reliable strategy for this patient, and it might increase thirst. Increased solute intake can be used in chronic cases to aid in management.

E) INCORRECT:

Hypertonic (3%) normal saline is a treatment for life-threatening hyponatremia and is reserved for the acute setting in patients who have clear neurologic symptoms.

questions.text:
A 7-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department for labored breathing and high fever that developed earlier today. His parents report that he has had a cough and congestion for several days but has otherwise been healthy. He has been eating less than usual but has not vomited or had diarrhea. He is up to date with Covid-19 vaccinations, and testing for SARS-CoV-2 is negative.
A chest radiograph reveals a right lower lobe consolidation, and the patient is admitted to the pediatric inpatient unit for intravenous antibiotics. He is not taking any other medications.
On physical examination, his condition is nontoxic, and he is tachypneic. His heart rate is 124 beats per minute, his respiratory rate is 25 breaths per minute, his oxygen saturation is 92% while he is breathing ambient air, and his blood pressure is 97/57 mm Hg. He has crackles over his right lower lobe. He has no heart murmur, edema, jaundice, or hepatosplenomegaly. The rest of his physical examination is unremarkable.
Laboratory findings are as follows:



Patient value
Reference range


Leukocyte count (per mm3)
21,000
5000– 14,500


Polymorphonuclear leukocytes (%)
79
40–70


Sodium (mEq/liter)
124
135–147

4.0
3.4–4.7


Chloride (mEq/liter)
100

Bicarbonate (mEq/liter)
